awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Linking turbulent flow dynamics to meandering river migration
awd_abstract_narration:
Rivers are central conduits for life in the US. They are thoroughfares for shipping, focal points for infrastructure and manufacturing, and oases for recreation and wildlife. Rivers often migrate as a natural process, one which has far-reaching consequences: it poses hazards to bridges and other infrastructure; shifts flooding patterns; and over geologic time, shapes underground resources, including groundwater and hydrocarbons. This project advances the field of Earth-surface science by building new tools to forecast river migration and a new, related curriculum for college science classes. The project will further diversity in the sciences by supporting a team of women and men from the mountain west to the east coast, who together represent two state universities and one Tribal College.

A foundation of the research is a new set of state-of-the-art mathematical simulations using higher-performance computing techniques. These simulations will capture interactions between water flow and sediment transport across an unprecedented range of river shapes. Model predictions will be tested and refined using experiments in a scale model of a meandering river, and by comparison to geologic data sets. The research findings will help geologists, engineers, and river scientists to mitigate river hazards, manage wildlife habitat, and identify natural resources spanning the changing landscapes of the nation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
This research project aimed to study the turbulent flow and morphodynamics of meandering rivers under flood and normal flow conditions. We developed and validated a high-fidelity numerical model (VFS) and artificial intelligence (AI) to achieve the goals of this project.

The high-fidelity model was employed to study flood flows impact on infrastructure in California and Minnesota. The findings of these studies demonstrated how flood flows lead to the collapse of infrastructures and provided guidelines on how to prevent and/or mitigate these effects. 

The developed and validated AI algorithms allow us to predict 3D flood flows in large scales at a small fraction of the cost associated with high-fidelity models. 

The findings and outcomes of this paper can be summarized as follows:

1- VFS model can successfully predict the flood flow and bed deformation of large-scale rivers to provide insight into the effect of flood on river ecosystem and infrastructure intalled in them,

2- For the first time, we developed AI algorithms that can predict the flood flow field of large-scale rivers to provide insight into the potential impact of floods on the river ecosystems,

3- This project provided support for 1 MS student and 2 PhD students. 

4- The results of this project have been published in over 16 peer-review research articles in top-tier journals.


Last Modified: 09/02/2022
Modified by: Ali Khosronejad

Image
  • Computed bed bathymetry of the 42 meandering river testbeds at the dynamic equilibrium state. Color maps show the bed elevation (Zb) of the channels at dynamic equilibrium and relative to their initial flat-bed state. Elevation values are normalized by the mean-flow depth (H) of each river.
    Ali Khosronejad
    Copyrighted
    Ali Khosronejad
    Computed topography of various large-scale meandering rivers
